69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:37): that particular bug is ridiculous
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:37): i don't even understand how we got there
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:37): who implements those two functions as synonyms?!
3a11d663baf9dd49fd3266d53d9bec5c (21:39): has a look at bonsai
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (21:40): the longer you wait, the more pressure builds on us to drop ours
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (21:40): sorta like our stance on WebM
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:40): I'll bring it up at the f2f.  It's Apple people who were fighting it.
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (21:41): does it need to be Webkit-wide?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:41): It's best for it to be so, yes.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:41): We try and minimize platform differences.
3a11d663baf9dd49fd3266d53d9bec5c (21:41): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, <email/> ;)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:41): (Despite the fact that Apple's already forked WebKit...)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:42): For all practical purposes, iOS uses a fork.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:42): 3a11d663baf9dd49fd3266d53d9bec5c: kiiiippppp! figures.
3a11d663baf9dd49fd3266d53d9bec5c (21:42): (Revision 1.1 of nsGlobalWindow.cpp has it)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:42): Not sure if iBooks uses the iOS fork or a new one, but it's in the same boat.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:43): 3a11d663baf9dd49fd3266d53d9bec5c: probably brendan's fault in a netscape < 4
3a11d663baf9dd49fd3266d53d9bec5c (21:43): Might very well have been
3a11d663baf9dd49fd3266d53d9bec5c (21:43): But that isn't on MXR, afaik
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:44): indeed
3a11d663baf9dd49fd3266d53d9bec5c (21:44): I'd look up what Opera does, but they don't let me :(
127ae7838c8d29977d0b96a1600a2c4d (21:59): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: I've been told that iBooks is using Pages, not Webkit
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:02): 127ae7838c8d29977d0b96a1600a2c4d: That doesn't seem correct from what I've seen, but I'm not certain.
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:05): hyatt did a lot of Webkit work for iBooks (possibly an older version though)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:06): iBooks is certainly using WebKit, as can be seen if you open up the ZIP archive.
127ae7838c8d29977d0b96a1600a2c4d (22:07): the markup is one thing, the engine displaying that markup might be something else. I don't know for sure, though.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:07): I doubt it's anything but WebKit given the number of -webkit- prefixes in it.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:09): surely not even microsoft would use a word processor engine to render html content
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:09): oh wait
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (22:09): is staying out of this one

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:11): It's just a little bit up the scrollback, dude.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:11): since he's still working on fullscreen
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (22:12): yeah, the www-style thread on that didn't go anywhere iirc
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:12): we need to figure out how the css parts of dialog and fullscreen work before i spec <dialog>
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:12): It was about ::cover, and how it interacted with multiple dialogs (modal and not) and fullscreen.
